The king woke up and fell asleep again. The snake came out again, wanting to bite the king. The rat made a sound again, coming down to awaken the king.
When the king got up, he saw a large poisonous snake in the cave under the tree. He was frightened and looked around for the entertainers, but he did not see them again. The king thought to himself:

The king then contemplated wanting to repay the kindness of the rat.

At that time, there was a village on the side of the mountain. The king ordered the village, From now on, all my salary and provisions will be turned over to feed the rat. Because of this rat, the village was named Kalandaka Village.

The son of Kalanda means that at that time there was an elder in the village who had 40 billion gold coins. The king bestowed the position of elder upon him, and because of the name of the village, he was called the elder Kalanda.
The Dharma teacher asked:

Acquaintances means sharing in suffering and joy.
At that time, there was an occasion when he went to Vaishali. The occasion was to search for a debtor.
There is also a Dharma teacher who says:
On the ninth day of the ninth month, the people of the country gather to play. For this reason, Sudinna went to watch.
At that time, the World-Honored One arrived in Vaishali on the fifteenth day before the ninth month.
He asked:
What is meant by 'seeing'?

SÅ«danna, having finished his meal in the morning, saw people bare their right shoulders, carrying various flowers and incense to the Buddha's place, wanting to make offerings and listen to the Dharma, going out of the city gate. SÅ«danna, having seen this, asked:

They replied:

SÅ«danna said:

At that time, the World-Honored One was surrounded by the four assemblies, expounding the Dharma with the Brahma voice. SÅ«danna, having arrived, saw the Buddha expounding the Dharma for the great assembly, so the Vinaya text is called 'seeing.'
The Dharma teacher said:
This is SÅ«danna's past meritorious cause that caused him to awaken.
SÅ«danna thought to himself:
'What causes and conditions can I find to enter and listen to the Dharma?
Why is it so?
Because the four assemblies surround him and listen to the Dharma with utmost sincerity, it is difficult to move and hard to enter.'
At that time, Sthitamati, the son of Kalanda, gradually approached the assembly.
He asked:
Why didn't he enter the assembly?
He replied:
Because he arrived later, he sat near the edge of the assembly.
The Vinaya scriptures say, Sthitamati, the son of Kalanda, went to the assembly and sat in one place. Sthitamati, the son of Kalanda, thought like this.
He asked:
Did he think this after sitting down?
Or did he think this after hearing the Dharma?
He replied:
He thought this after hearing the Buddha praise morality, concentration, and wisdom.
He asked:
What did he think?
He replied:
He should have thought like this:

'The Buddha explained the Dharma one by one, and I have already understood it. After contemplating it repeatedly, the meaning and principles within morality, concentration, and wisdom are of one flavor.' Thinking like this:
It is very difficult for me to practice the precepts, concentration, wisdom, and pure conduct at home for even a single day. It is not suitable to stay at home, like a polisher.
He asked:
What is meant by polishing?
He replied:
Just as a person who polishes can make it extremely white and pure, it is also very difficult to practice at home like a polisher.
How can I now shave my beard and hair, put on the Dharma robes, and practice pure conduct, so that I can leave the household life and enter the homeless life?
He asked:
What is meant by the household life and the homeless life?
He replied:
The household life means plowing fields, planting crops, selling goods, and various occupations;
The homeless life means being free from all occupations, tranquil and desireless. This is called leaving the household life and entering the homeless life.

The assembly had not risen for long when he went to where the Buddha was means that when the assembly of Sudinna had not yet risen, he went to where the Buddha was without seeking to leave the household life.
Why is it so?
If someone seeks to go forth, if their siblings and relatives are sitting listening to the Dharma, they should create obstacles and say:
'Your parents only have you as a child. If you seek to go forth, who will serve and support them?'
Having said this, they will definitely take you back, making it difficult for you to go forth.
Sunetra withdrew with the assembly, but after walking a few steps, he turned back and went to where the Buddha was, and then sought to go forth.
Therefore, the Vinaya text says, 'Not long after the assembly arose, Sunetra went to where the Buddha was.'
'May the World-Honored One, after RÄhula goes forth, if his parents do not allow him to go forth, the Buddha should not allow it.'
Therefore, the Buddha asked Sunetra:

The Dharma teacher said:

Amada means mother in Chinese, and da means father. You is easy to understand. Only child means you have only one child and no siblings.

Sudinna immediately got up from the ground, overjoyed. Sudinna said to the patron,

Sudinna replied:

He asked:

He asked:

Sudinna did not do this. He actually engaged in impure acts. Men and women with lust and desire united and conceived. All three things united and then gave birth to a child. Sudinna was like this.
At that time, the earth spirit saw Sudinna engaging in impure acts, and immediately cried out loudly, No one knows that all who commit evil deeds will be punished.

The first doer is seen by the spirit that protects the body. Next, the heavenly beings who know others' minds know. Such a person is seen by both heavenly beings and spirits, and therefore cries out loudly.
Passing it on to each other until it reaches Brahma Heaven means that except for the formless realm, the rest all hear and know about it.

At that time, the child gradually grew up and left home together with his mother means that at the age of eight, he left home together with his mother who continued the lineage. Therefore, the Vinaya text says, They left home together and in turn attained the fruit of arhatship.
Immediately giving rise to a repentant mind means that since one has previously engaged in impure conduct, one constantly gives rise to a repentant mind day and night.

Not obtaining the benefits for oneself means that within the Buddha's teachings, one cultivates pure conduct and attains the wisdom of the three insights, but one does not obtain these benefits, which is called not obtaining these benefits for oneself.
I have obtained evil benefits means that other people who have gone forth obtain good benefits, but I do not obtain good benefits but obtain evil benefits.

Emaciated means that due to self-reproach, one's food and drink are obstructed, and therefore one's blood and flesh wither away.

At that time, the bhiká¹£us each came out of their rooms to play, and saw that Sudinna was emaciated and asked:

The bhiká¹£us said to Sudinna:

The bhiká¹£us said to Sudinna:

Then the bhiká¹£us devised a means to release SÅ«tra-dhÄna's mind and said to him:
It is not so, elder!

The Buddha uses various means to explain the Dharma to those who are detached from desire. The reason the Buddha explains the five desires of all beings in the three realms is to make them detach from desire and not allow them to unite, speaking differently while the meaning is the same.
Explaining the Dharma to make love end means to reach nirvÄá¹‡a and not dwell in the three realms, so he does not allow love.
The Buddha has already explained desire like this, making it distinct and not shared.
What you are doing now is uniting. The Buddha explains to be apart from impure conduct, yet you and the former two engage in impure conduct.
This meaning is easy to understand.

The Buddha explains the Dharma in various ways to make one apart from confusion. The reason the Buddha explains the Dharma for beings is to make them eliminate confusion and cut off thirst. The reason all beings thirst for the five desires is because the Buddha explains the Dharma to make beings cut off their thirst.
Cutting off the seeds means that the Buddha teaches the Dharma to cut off the seeds of the three realms. When craving is exhausted, one attains nirvana.
Craving refers to the craving and desire of the three realms. The reason sentient beings cannot escape is because they are bound by craving and desire.
Exhaustion means the extinction of craving. One who attains nirvana is so called.

Within the three realms, the four modes of birth, the five destinies, the seven abodes of consciousness, and the nine abodes of sentient beings, one goes from here to there and returns from there to here, just like a needle and thread piercing through the holes in a garment, binding them together. Not unravelling craving is binding, and exhausting it is extinguishing. One who exhausts craving is one who attains nirvana.
Moreover, nirvana is said to be non-weaving.
The Buddha says that those who eliminate desire should eliminate the desires for the five sense objects and the afflictions.
Knowing desire means that one should know each and every desire and subdue it. This is called knowing.
Thirsting for desire means seeking desire to the utmost in all desires.
Thinking and desire means having thoughts and desires together.
Thinking and vexation in desire means thinking about the five desires that have not been obtained and giving rise to vexation.
This is all said to be the truth of the path. The previous sentence speaks of worldly dharmas, and the latter sentence speaks of supramundane dharmas.

The elder who is a person without faith causes those who have faith to lose faith is because he creates evil dharmas. A person who has not yet given rise to faith cannot be caused to give rise to faith.
The elder who has faith further turns his mind.

Turning the mind means that one gives rise to regret and remorse in the Dharma with a mind of faith. If a person has faith in the path, it is like Mount Sumeru, which cannot be moved by the winds from the four directions. This mind of faith is also like this.
Therefore, it is said in the Vinaya scriptures, There are people like this, and there are people not like this.

At that time the bhiká¹£us reported the matter to the World-Honored One. The reason for gathering the bhiká¹£u saá¹…gha is because of Sudinna's evil conduct that goes against the sage's Dharma, and therefore the bhiká¹£u saá¹…gha is gathered.

if there are those who can uphold the precepts and diligently practice, they should be praised. The TathÄgata then praises them.

Not knowing contentment means abiding in the place of concealment. It is called not knowing contentment because even if one obtains precious treasures like Mount Sumeru, it still does not satisfy the mind. Therefore, it is called not knowing contentment.
As for speaking of the body gathering in one place, it means gathering in one place and praising each other, or praising out of afflictions.
As for the lazy, they have all eight kinds of work. The TathÄgata skillfully praises those with few desires and contentment, who are easy to support and raise.

Those with few desires have no stingy or greedy mind. If they receive a single offering, they follow what they have obtained. If they uphold being easy to support, they are able to control the six senses and not follow the six sense objects. This is called being easy to support.

As for being easy to raise, they know the measure and are content with the four kinds of offerings. This is called being easy to raise. Whether coarse or fine, they accept what they obtain, because of having few desires, which is the same as being content.
As for purity, it is called purity because of having few desires and contentment.

It is also said that the three karmas are all pure, and they abandon the three unwholesome karmas. No one criticizes them. This is called upright.
As for not accumulating, they conceal the afflictions of the body, causing them to develop and disperse. This is called not accumulating.
Because of non-aggregation, one is courageous and diligent.

As for causing the true Dharma to abide for a long time, there are three kinds of true Dharma.

For those who value the Vinaya, because there are precepts to be observed, there are the Vinaya of concealment, the Vinaya of abandonment, the Vinaya of rectification, and the Vinaya of establishing precepts. These four Vinayas are highly valued.

The Dharma master said:

At that time there was a bhiká¹£u, the meaning of this phrase is easy to understand.

As for 'luring the monkey with food and drink', at that time in the great forest there were many bhiká¹£us who practiced the mind of loving-kindness and compassion. This monkey had previously engaged in impure acts with a monk. When the monkey saw the monks coming, it thought that all the monks were no different from the previous monk. It went there and used its genitals to show the monks, raising its tail to reveal itself and wait.
Fearing that the monks all had lustful intentions.
After not seeing them for a long time, it then made its own sexual gestures to show the monks.
The monks knew that the monkey wanted to engage in sexual activity. The monks said:
We can wait in a secluded place until the alms-round monk returns. We will then see what he does.
It is definitely the elder. What is certain is not false, like a thief who fully collects his loot and does not dare to hide it.
Is it really the elder who does not do such things?
The female sex organ of a woman and the female sex organ of an animal are not different. The precepts established by the Buddha are all for this matter.
If one sees a human woman, whether seen, touched, or fondled, and engages in impure acts, it is the same with the female sex organ of an animal. All actions are evil dharmas.
You, elder, you commit this offense in this way, even with an animal, you incur the pÄrÄjika offense and should not be allowed to stay.
If one engages in impure acts with the female sex organ of an animal, it is also said to constitute the pÄrÄjika offense.
The Dharma teacher said:

The precepts are established to be firm. There are two dharmas for the precepts: first, naturally committing offenses in the world; second, committing offenses by going against the words of the sages.

If the mind reveres evil dharmas, it is naturally committing offenses in the world. The other offenses are the offenses established by the TathÄgata's precepts. Now, the remaining dharmas all arise from Devadatta. Just as Devadatta obtained the support of the Bhadra group and split the harmonious Saá¹ƒgha, this arises from the Bhadra group.

Question:

Question:
